greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = binomial(6*n,3*n).
comment: For the trisection of a sequence (here A000984) given by its real o.g.f. see a comment and a reference under A187357.
link: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..100
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} Sum_{j=0..n} Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n, i)*binomial(n, j) *binomial(n, k)*binomial(3n, i+j+k). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Mar 08 2005

O.g.f.(with a(0):=1): (cb(x^(1/3)) + sqrt(2)*P(x^(1/3))*sqrt(1/P(x^(1/3))+1+2*x^(1/3)))/3, with cb(x):=1/sqrt(1-4*x) (o.g.f. of A000984) and P(x):=P(-1/2,4*x)= 1/sqrt(1+4*x+16*x^2) (o.g.f. of A116091, with P(x,z) the o.g.f. of the Legendre polynomials). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Mar 24 2011
Supercongruences: a(m*p^k) == a(m*p^(k-1)) ( mod p^(3*k) ) for prime p >= 5 and positive integers m and k.
program: (PARI) { for (n=0, 100, write("b066802.txt", n, " ", binomial(6*n, 3*n)) ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Mar 28 2010
(Sage) [binomial(6*n, 3*n) for n in (0..15)] # _G. C. Greubel_, Feb 17 2020
results.author: _Benoit Cloitre_, Jan 18 2002
ext: Extended to a(0)=1 by _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 06 2014
